description.narrative: FAIR Company Community Partnership comprises four principles of Freedom of Choices, Accountability, Improvement of Benefits, and Respect for Rights. The long-term objective of FAIR Partnerships implementation is to demonstrate a holistic landscape level approach in Indonesia in support of community/smallholder-inclusive growth in the palm oil sector. Building on continued interest from PepsiCo and following the geographic priorities as directed by the Indonesian government, Oxfam has shifted its focus to local economic development needs in Sulawesi. A scoping study for selecting intervention area based on the target commodities (palm oil, cocoa and coconut) is done and has resulted in the decision to proceed with the Co-Creation and Preparation Phase ofFAIR Project in North Konawe, South East Sulawesi. A consortium of Oxfam in Indonesia with three local CSOs (JKPP, TUK, and Teras) has taken on thepreparations/inception and implementation of the pilot project. The CSO consortium secured the interest in the FAIR partnership pilot from affected local communities and related independent smallholders, initial buy in from the two mills in the landscape of North Konawe and serious support from the local government agencies. Oxfam's programming history, reputation and strong relationships with civil society, government, development partners, research institutions and private sector actors provide project legitimacy and acceptance from project participants and the wider community. Oxfam's effective role as a 'meeting initiator, facilitator, intermediary / broker' means that the FAIR Partnership project is well placed to connect project participants with various stakeholders so that their needs and priorities can be better addressed through direct action and a more enabling environment. 2. Vision Realizing a new “green sustainable growth” business model through the application of the FAIR Partnership by prioritizing land use for diversifiedlivelihoods for farmer and women as well as learning with the explanation as below:: • FAIR Partnership offer a model for sustainable commodities that promotes food security and development aspirations of women and smallholder farmers. It also provides a pathway for companies to implement their sustainability commitment. FAIR stands for 1) Freedom of choice; 2) Accountability; 3) Improvement and sharing of benefits; and 4) Respect for rights and the environment. • Green sustainable growth is a coordinated movement consisting of economic growth, environmental sustainability, poverty reduction and social inclusion driven by the development and sustainable use of global resources. • Diversified livelihoods mean a process of sustainable adaptation for households in building an increasingly diverse portfolio of activities and assets to survive and improve their standard of living. • Farmer and Women are the principle of prioritizing the widest possible involvement, in favor and usefulness for farmer and women in the components and activities ofprogram implementation. Iterative learning and adaptive management approaches, MEAL is an integral part of the program as it will enable adaptive management of the program (and its theory of change) based on evidence, learning and change occurring in a broader context.

participating-org.narrative:
We have a vision of an Indonesia where people live equitably and free from the injustice of poverty, enjoy their rights, and are resilient in times of disasters. Women and girls are at the heart of all our strategies to achieve this vision.
We have been working with local and national partners in Indonesia since 1957.
We are currently working in 8 provinces where we are support the Government of Indonesia, civil society, and local communities on the following main issues:
Gender justice: We workto help women and girls participate equally in all economic, social, political and cultural aspects of their lives, to have leadership roles, access to resources and services and participate in decisions that affect their lives. Economic justice: We support marginalized small holder farmers, especially women, to adapt to climate change and improve their food security. We promote inclusive natural resource management and to promote private sector accountability which encourages respect for worker’s rights. Rights in crisis: We promote risk management as everybody’s business, to strengthen and mobilize the capacity of urban areas to respond to natural disasters. We promote themainstreaming of gender in all response intervention conducted by national and sub-national governments.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

description.narrative: Companies run fairer, more inclusive, more impact driven and sustainable business, financed by critical and supportive financial institutions and/or apply alternative buisness models
alternative business models / more inclusive practices in existing value chains ( adopted by private sector)
cases of private sector actors engaged in co-creating and/or promoting alternative business models/practices and/or enabling environment
cases of private sector actors implementing alternative business practice
cases of small impact-driven businesses, that apply alternative business models and run their businesses in inclusive, fair and sustainable way as example of the human economy.
cases where companies adopt policies which prevent negative community externalities, advance the voice, ownership and interests of small-scale producers and food workers, and impact on women’s lives;
cases where companies practically prevent negative community externalities, advance the voice, ownership and interests of small-scale producers and food workers, and impact on women’s lives;

cases where development banks and financial institutions adopt human rights due-diligence policies and practices and actively support innovative, sustainable and inclusive business conduct and practices
cases where financial institutions and impact investors provide access to finance to small-scale food producers and small impact-driven businesses
cases where multi-stakeholder initiatives more effectively address small-scale producers and food workers' rights,
cases where standard setting bodies revise their criteria
